cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
What Caribbean nation is considered the first black-led republic in the world?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To determine which Caribbean nation is the first black-led republic in the world, we need to consider the history of the Caribbean and the context of black leadership. The term "black-led republic" typically refers to a nation that was established and governed by people of African descent, particularly following the end of colonial rule or slavery. 

Haiti is a significant nation in this context. It was the first country in the world to successfully overthrow colonial rule and establish a government led by former enslaved people. The Haitian Revolution, which took place from 1791 to 1804, resulted in Haiti declaring its independence from France on January 1, 1804. This event marked the establishment of Haiti as the first black-led republic in the world.

Answer: Haiti

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
What Caribbean nation is considered the first black-led republic in the world?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Carib Queen is the leader of the indigenous community in Trinidad and Tobago. The Queen, whose title was established in 1875, is based at the Santa Rosa First Peoples Community in Arima, Trinidad and Tobago. The position is a lifetime appointment.\n', 'The largest Costa Rican black community is from the Caribbean, which today constitutes the majority of the Costa Rican black population. Costa Rica has the largest Jamaican diaspora after Cuba and Panama and its development as a nation is witness to this contribution.\n', "Although the community does not face any official or informal restrictions on political participation, Britons of Caribbean origin are under-represented in local and national politics. However, there have been some successes with Labour MP Diane Abbott being the first Black person elected to the House of Commons in 1987. Elected alongside her were two other Afro-Caribbean Labour MPs, Bernie Grant and Paul Boateng. Linda C. Douglas was the first Black member of the party's National Executive Committee, representing the later expelled Militant tendency. British African-West Indians have long asserted that they encounter discriminatory barriers to most middle- and higher-status occupations, as well as discrimination in hiring practices at all levels of employment. There is also considerable evidence that African-Caribbean people experience differential treatment at the hands of public officials, the British courts and penal system, and the police. Studies have proposed that the isolation of certain regional urban areas by financial institutions such as insurance brokers disproportionately affects the community to its detriment.\n", 'Blackman is known for correcting any of the erroneous statements or reports made about Barbados in the International Community, in the past he often referred to the country of Barbados, as "the most successful predominantly black country in the world".\n', "Most of the black population in Panama is centered in the Province of Colon. Panama has two distinct groups of blacks. The first and earliest blacks were those who came as slaves as early as the fifteenth century, through much of the nineteenth century. They are of mixed African and Spanish descent. This group is known as Cimarrones, Afro Colonials, Nativos, Playeros, Congos. These terms have proven crucial in establishing that these are the first and original blacks of the Republic of Panama. Afro Colonials have held on to their culture and adopted Hispanic customs, traits, and cultures. They took and assumed Spanish names and surnames. They also developed the beginning of Panama's black population and culture, in pure and in mixed forms. They have been incorporated into Panamanian and Spanish-speaking society, as a result.\n", 'BULLET::::- The first black-led government of Rhodesia in 90 years takes power, in succession to Ian Smith and under his power-sharing deal.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1804 – French rule ends in Haiti. Haiti becomes the first black republic and second independent country in North America after the United States.\n', "Haiti is the world's oldest black republic and one of the oldest republics in the Western Hemisphere. Although Haiti actively assisted the independence movements of many Latin American countries – and secured a promise from the great liberator, Simón Bolívar, that he would free their slaves after winning independence from Spain – the nation of former slaves was excluded from the hemisphere's first regional meeting of independent nations, held in Panama in 1826. Furthermore, owing to entrenched opposition from Southern slave states, Haiti did not receive U.S. diplomatic recognition until 1862 (after those states had seceded from the Union) – largely through the efforts of anti-slavery senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts.\n", 'Black Caribs are an ethnic group native to the island of St. Vincent. Black Carib were historically referred to as "zambos", since they are descendants of Island Caribs and enslaved Africans who mixed among themselves in the 18th century. This population retains Caribbean culture and makes up a very small population in the archipelago, representing the 2.0% of the current population of St. Vincent and Grenadines. There are also black Caribs in Dominica and Trinidad. The history of the Black Caribs is known due to reports that the British governor William Young sent to the British crown, in which he explained that the Black Caribs were a mix of Caribs and enslaved Africans from Spanish ships wrecked near its shores. These reports were read and taken as reference by many chroniclers and later historians. However, researchers of history and Garifuna language (the Garifunas are descendants of Black Caribs in the mainland of Central America) of the 20th and 21st centuries, such as Itarala, have their own conception of the origin of the Black Caribs. According to them, the African ancestors of the Black Caribs come from other Caribbean islands and migrated to Saint Vincent as refugees to escape slavery and as slaves bought by the Carib Amerindians. The Black Caribs are the people who originated the Garifuna people, when part of their community was expelled from St. Vincent in 1797 and exported to the island of Roatán, Honduras, from where they migrated to the coast of the mainland of Central America, spread as far as Belize and Nicaragua.\n', 'BULLET::::- First Blacks in the Americas: the African presence in the Dominican Republic (CUNY Dominican Studies Institute)\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To address the question regarding the first black-led republic in the world, we can extract relevant content from the provided passages and analyze its significance.

### Relevant Extracted Content:
1. **Haiti's Historical Context**:
   - "1804 – French rule ends in Haiti. Haiti becomes the first black republic and second independent country in North America after the United States."
   - "Haiti is the world's oldest black republic and one of the oldest republics in the Western Hemisphere."

### Analysis of the Extracted Content:
- **Historical Significance**: The passages highlight Haiti's pivotal role in history as the first black-led republic, established after a successful slave revolt against French colonial rule. This context is crucial for understanding Haiti's significance not only in the Caribbean but also in the broader narrative of global history regarding race, independence, and governance.
  
- **Cultural and Political Impact**: The establishment of Haiti as a black republic had profound implications for other nations, particularly in the Americas. It served as an inspiration for other independence movements and challenged the prevailing notions of racial hierarchy and colonialism. The mention of Haiti's exclusion from early diplomatic recognition and regional meetings underscores the political challenges faced by the nation due to its revolutionary status.

- **Legacy of Resistance**: The passage also hints at Haiti's role in supporting other independence movements in Latin America, showcasing its influence beyond its borders. This aspect of Haiti's history is essential for understanding the interconnectedness of struggles for freedom and equality across the region.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content provides a foundational understanding of Haiti's historical significance as the first black-led republic. It emphasizes the importance of Haiti in the context of global history, particularly regarding race relations, colonialism, and the fight for independence. This background knowledge is crucial for answering the question accurately and comprehensively.

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:
To determine which Caribbean nation is considered the first black-led republic in the world, we need to analyze the historical context of black leadership in the Caribbean. The term "black-led republic" refers to a nation established and governed by people of African descent, particularly following the end of colonial rule or slavery.

Haiti emerges as a significant nation in this context. It was the first country in the world to successfully overthrow colonial rule and establish a government led by former enslaved people. The Haitian Revolution, which took place from 1791 to 1804, culminated in Haiti declaring its independence from France on January 1, 1804. This event marked the establishment of Haiti as the first black-led republic in the world.

The historical significance of Haiti cannot be overstated. It is not only the first black republic but also the second independent country in North America after the United States. The successful revolt against French colonialism set a precedent for other nations and inspired various independence movements across the Americas. Furthermore, Haiti's establishment as a black republic challenged the prevailing notions of racial hierarchy and colonialism, making it a symbol of resistance and empowerment for oppressed peoples worldwide.

Despite its revolutionary achievements, Haiti faced significant political challenges, including exclusion from early diplomatic recognition and regional meetings, which reflected the entrenched racism and opposition from other nations, particularly those with slaveholding interests. This context is essential for understanding Haiti's role in the broader narrative of global history regarding race, independence, and governance.

Additionally, Haiti's legacy of resistance and support for other independence movements in Latin America highlights its influence beyond its borders. This interconnectedness of struggles for freedom and equality is crucial for comprehending the historical impact of Haiti as the first black-led republic.

### Answer:
Haiti is considered the first black-led republic in the world, having declared its independence from France on January 1, 1804, following a successful revolution led by former enslaved people.

The question asks about the Caribbean nation that is considered the first black-led republic in the world. The relevant information extracted from the provided passages indicates that Haiti is recognized as the first black republic, having gained independence from French rule in 1804. This historical context is significant as it marks Haiti not only as the first black-led republic but also as the second independent country in North America after the United States.

### Key Points from the Passages:

1. **Haiti's Historical Significance**:
   - Haiti became the first black republic in 1804 after the end of French colonial rule. This event is pivotal in the context of global history, as it represents a successful slave revolt leading to the establishment of a nation governed by formerly enslaved people.

2. **Recognition and Diplomatic Challenges**:
   - Despite its early independence, Haiti faced significant challenges, including exclusion from regional meetings of independent nations and delayed diplomatic recognition from the United States until 1862. This reflects the geopolitical dynamics of the time, particularly the resistance from slave-holding states in the U.S.

3. **Cultural and Political Impact**:
   - Haiti's independence had a profound impact on the Caribbean and Latin America, inspiring other independence movements. The nation actively supported liberation efforts in neighboring countries, showcasing its role as a beacon of freedom.

4. **Demographics and Identity**:
   - The passages also touch on the broader African diaspora in the Caribbean and the historical presence of black communities in various nations, such as Panama and Costa Rica. However, these do not directly relate to the question of the first black-led republic.

### Analysis of the Role of These Contents:

- **Foundational Knowledge**: The information about Haiti's independence and its status as the first black republic is foundational to understanding the historical context of black leadership and governance in the Caribbean. It highlights the significance of Haiti's revolution in the broader narrative of colonialism and the fight for freedom.

- **Advanced Information**: The challenges Haiti faced post-independence, including diplomatic isolation and the socio-political dynamics with other nations, provide a deeper understanding of the complexities surrounding Haiti's status as a black-led republic. This context is crucial for comprehending the long-term implications of its independence on both regional and global scales.

### Conclusion:

In summary, Haiti is the first black-led republic in the world, a fact that is underscored by its historical struggle for independence and the subsequent challenges it faced. This knowledge not only answers the question but also enriches the understanding of the broader implications of Haiti's independence on the Caribbean and the African diaspora. The passages collectively emphasize the importance of Haiti in the context of black leadership and the ongoing legacy of its revolutionary history.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine which Caribbean nation is considered the first black-led republic in the world, we must analyze the historical context of black leadership and governance in the Caribbean. The term "black-led republic" specifically refers to a nation established and governed by people of African descent, particularly following the end of colonial rule or slavery.

Haiti stands out prominently in this context. It was the first country in the world to successfully overthrow colonial rule and establish a government led by former enslaved people. The Haitian Revolution, which began in 1791 and culminated in Haiti declaring its independence from France on January 1, 1804, is a landmark event in global history. This revolution not only marked the end of slavery in Haiti but also established the nation as the first black-led republic in the world.

### Key Points to Enhance Understanding:

1. **Haiti's Historical Significance**:
   - Haiti's independence in 1804 is a pivotal moment that symbolizes the successful resistance against colonial oppression. It is essential to recognize that this was not merely a political change but a profound social transformation, as it represented the first time a nation was governed by formerly enslaved individuals.

2. **Recognition and Diplomatic Challenges**:
   - Following its independence, Haiti faced significant diplomatic challenges, including exclusion from international recognition and participation in regional meetings. The United States, influenced by its own slave-holding states, did not recognize Haiti until 1862. This isolation had lasting effects on Haiti's political and economic development.

3. **Cultural and Political Impact**:
   - Haiti's revolution inspired other independence movements across the Caribbean and Latin America, making it a beacon of hope for oppressed peoples. The Haitian Revolution demonstrated that enslaved individuals could successfully fight for their freedom and self-governance, influencing revolutionary movements globally.

4. **Demographics and Identity**:
   - The broader context of the African diaspora in the Caribbean is important, as it highlights the interconnectedness of black communities across the region. However, Haiti's unique position as the first black-led republic sets it apart in terms of historical significance and the implications of its independence.

5. **Legacy and Ongoing Challenges**:
   - The legacy of Haiti's independence is complex. While it is celebrated as a triumph of freedom, the nation has faced ongoing challenges, including political instability, economic hardship, and natural disasters. Understanding these challenges is crucial for comprehending Haiti's current status and its historical trajectory.

### Conclusion:

In summary, Haiti is unequivocally recognized as the first black-led republic in the world, a fact underscored by its revolutionary struggle for independence and the subsequent challenges it faced. This knowledge not only answers the question but also enriches our understanding of the broader implications of Haiti's independence on the Caribbean and the African diaspora. The historical significance of Haiti as a symbol of resistance and self-determination continues to resonate today.

### Answer:
Haiti

2. **Implications of Recognition**:

3. **Broader Context of Independence Movements**:

4. **Causal Relationships**:

To determine which Caribbean nation is the first black-led republic in the world, we need to consider the history of the Caribbean and the context of black leadership. The term "black-led republic" typically refers to a nation that was established and governed by people of African descent, particularly following the end of colonial rule or slavery.

The Haitian Revolution, which took place from 1791 to 1804, resulted in Haiti declaring its independence from France on January 1, 1804. This event marked the establishment of Haiti as the first black-led republic in the world.

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine which Caribbean nation is considered the first black-led republic in the world, we must analyze the historical context surrounding black leadership and independence movements in the Caribbean. The term "black-led republic" refers to a nation established and governed by individuals of African descent, particularly following the end of colonial rule or slavery.

**Haiti's Historical Context**:
- Haiti is pivotal in this discussion as it was the first country to successfully overthrow colonial rule and establish a government led by former enslaved people. The Haitian Revolution, which occurred from 1791 to 1804, culminated in Haiti declaring its independence from France on January 1, 1804. This event is significant as it marked the establishment of Haiti as the first black-led republic in the world.

**Political Recognition**:
- Following its independence, Haiti faced significant challenges, including a lack of diplomatic recognition from other nations. Notably, it did not receive U.S. diplomatic recognition until 1862, largely due to the political dynamics of the time, including the influence of anti-slavery advocates like Senator Charles Sumner. This delayed recognition underscores the racial and political implications of Haiti's independence.

**Broader Context of Independence Movements**:
- Haiti's successful revolution not only established it as a black-led republic but also inspired other independence movements across Latin America and the Caribbean. The nation actively assisted in these movements, showcasing its role as a beacon of freedom for enslaved and colonized peoples.

**Causal Relationships**:
- The historical events surrounding Haiti's revolution and subsequent struggles for recognition illustrate a clear cause-and-effect relationship. The success of the Haitian Revolution influenced other nations and highlighted the complexities of international relations, particularly regarding race and governance.

**Implications for Causal Reasoning**:
- Understanding Haiti's historical significance allows for a deeper comprehension of the interconnectedness of regional histories and the impact of one nation's actions on others. This knowledge enhances the model's ability to draw parallels and make informed inferences about contemporary issues related to race, governance, and international relations.

### Conclusion:
By integrating this historical context, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. The rich tapestry of Haiti's history as the first black-led republic, its struggles for recognition, and its influence on regional independence movements provides essential insights into the complexities of social and political dynamics.

### Answer:
Haiti is considered the first black-led republic in the world, having declared its independence from France on January 1, 1804, following a successful revolution led by former enslaved people.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
What Caribbean nation is considered the first black-led republic in the world?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Carib Queen is the leader of the indigenous community in Trinidad and Tobago. The Queen, whose title was established in 1875, is based at the Santa Rosa First Peoples Community in Arima, Trinidad and Tobago. The position is a lifetime appointment.\n', 'The largest Costa Rican black community is from the Caribbean, which today constitutes the majority of the Costa Rican black population. Costa Rica has the largest Jamaican diaspora after Cuba and Panama and its development as a nation is witness to this contribution.\n', "Although the community does not face any official or informal restrictions on political participation, Britons of Caribbean origin are under-represented in local and national politics. However, there have been some successes with Labour MP Diane Abbott being the first Black person elected to the House of Commons in 1987. Elected alongside her were two other Afro-Caribbean Labour MPs, Bernie Grant and Paul Boateng. Linda C. Douglas was the first Black member of the party's National Executive Committee, representing the later expelled Militant tendency. British African-West Indians have long asserted that they encounter discriminatory barriers to most middle- and higher-status occupations, as well as discrimination in hiring practices at all levels of employment. There is also considerable evidence that African-Caribbean people experience differential treatment at the hands of public officials, the British courts and penal system, and the police. Studies have proposed that the isolation of certain regional urban areas by financial institutions such as insurance brokers disproportionately affects the community to its detriment.\n", 'Blackman is known for correcting any of the erroneous statements or reports made about Barbados in the International Community, in the past he often referred to the country of Barbados, as "the most successful predominantly black country in the world".\n', "Most of the black population in Panama is centered in the Province of Colon. Panama has two distinct groups of blacks. The first and earliest blacks were those who came as slaves as early as the fifteenth century, through much of the nineteenth century. They are of mixed African and Spanish descent. This group is known as Cimarrones, Afro Colonials, Nativos, Playeros, Congos. These terms have proven crucial in establishing that these are the first and original blacks of the Republic of Panama. Afro Colonials have held on to their culture and adopted Hispanic customs, traits, and cultures. They took and assumed Spanish names and surnames. They also developed the beginning of Panama's black population and culture, in pure and in mixed forms. They have been incorporated into Panamanian and Spanish-speaking society, as a result.\n", 'BULLET::::- The first black-led government of Rhodesia in 90 years takes power, in succession to Ian Smith and under his power-sharing deal.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1804 – French rule ends in Haiti. Haiti becomes the first black republic and second independent country in North America after the United States.\n', "Haiti is the world's oldest black republic and one of the oldest republics in the Western Hemisphere. Although Haiti actively assisted the independence movements of many Latin American countries – and secured a promise from the great liberator, Simón Bolívar, that he would free their slaves after winning independence from Spain – the nation of former slaves was excluded from the hemisphere's first regional meeting of independent nations, held in Panama in 1826. Furthermore, owing to entrenched opposition from Southern slave states, Haiti did not receive U.S. diplomatic recognition until 1862 (after those states had seceded from the Union) – largely through the efforts of anti-slavery senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts.\n", 'Black Caribs are an ethnic group native to the island of St. Vincent. Black Carib were historically referred to as "zambos", since they are descendants of Island Caribs and enslaved Africans who mixed among themselves in the 18th century. This population retains Caribbean culture and makes up a very small population in the archipelago, representing the 2.0% of the current population of St. Vincent and Grenadines. There are also black Caribs in Dominica and Trinidad. The history of the Black Caribs is known due to reports that the British governor William Young sent to the British crown, in which he explained that the Black Caribs were a mix of Caribs and enslaved Africans from Spanish ships wrecked near its shores. These reports were read and taken as reference by many chroniclers and later historians. However, researchers of history and Garifuna language (the Garifunas are descendants of Black Caribs in the mainland of Central America) of the 20th and 21st centuries, such as Itarala, have their own conception of the origin of the Black Caribs. According to them, the African ancestors of the Black Caribs come from other Caribbean islands and migrated to Saint Vincent as refugees to escape slavery and as slaves bought by the Carib Amerindians. The Black Caribs are the people who originated the Garifuna people, when part of their community was expelled from St. Vincent in 1797 and exported to the island of Roatán, Honduras, from where they migrated to the coast of the mainland of Central America, spread as far as Belize and Nicaragua.\n', 'BULLET::::- First Blacks in the Americas: the African presence in the Dominican Republic (CUNY Dominican Studies Institute)\n']

question_info.question: What Caribbean nation is considered the first black-led republic in the world?
passages:
The Carib Queen is the leader of the indigenous community in Trinidad and Tobago. The Queen, whose title was established in 1875, is based at the Santa Rosa First Peoples Community in Arima, Trinidad and Tobago. The position is a lifetime appointment.
The largest Costa Rican black community is from the Caribbean, which today constitutes the majority of the Costa Rican black population. Costa Rica has the largest Jamaican diaspora after Cuba and Panama and its development as a nation is witness to this contribution.
Although the community does not face any official or informal restrictions on political participation, Britons of Caribbean origin are under-represented in local and national politics. However, there have been some successes with Labour MP Diane Abbott being the first Black person elected to the House of Commons in 1987. Elected alongside her were two other Afro-Caribbean Labour MPs, Bernie Grant and Paul Boateng. Linda C. Douglas was the first Black member of the party's National Executive Committee, representing the later expelled Militant tendency. British African-West Indians have long asserted that they encounter discriminatory barriers to most middle- and higher-status occupations, as well as discrimination in hiring practices at all levels of employment. There is also considerable evidence that African-Caribbean people experience differential treatment at the hands of public officials, the British courts and penal system, and the police. Studies have proposed that the isolation of certain regional urban areas by financial institutions such as insurance brokers disproportionately affects the community to its detriment.
Blackman is known for correcting any of the erroneous statements or reports made about Barbados in the International Community, in the past he often referred to the country of Barbados, as "the most successful predominantly black country in the world".
Most of the black population in Panama is centered in the Province of Colon. Panama has two distinct groups of blacks. The first and earliest blacks were those who came as slaves as early as the fifteenth century, through much of the nineteenth century. They are of mixed African and Spanish descent. This group is known as Cimarrones, Afro Colonials, Nativos, Playeros, Congos. These terms have proven crucial in establishing that these are the first and original blacks of the Republic of Panama. Afro Colonials have held on to their culture and adopted Hispanic customs, traits, and cultures. They took and assumed Spanish names and surnames. They also developed the beginning of Panama's black population and culture, in pure and in mixed forms. They have been incorporated into Panamanian and Spanish-speaking society, as a result.
BULLET::::- The first black-led government of Rhodesia in 90 years takes power, in succession to Ian Smith and under his power-sharing deal.
BULLET::::- 1804 – French rule ends in Haiti. Haiti becomes the first black republic and second independent country in North America after the United States.
Haiti is the world's oldest black republic and one of the oldest republics in the Western Hemisphere. Although Haiti actively assisted the independence movements of many Latin American countries – and secured a promise from the great liberator, Simón Bolívar, that he would free their slaves after winning independence from Spain – the nation of former slaves was excluded from the hemisphere's first regional meeting of independent nations, held in Panama in 1826. Furthermore, owing to entrenched opposition from Southern slave states, Haiti did not receive U.S. diplomatic recognition until 1862 (after those states had seceded from the Union) – largely through the efforts of anti-slavery senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts.
Black Caribs are an ethnic group native to the island of St. Vincent. Black Carib were historically referred to as "zambos", since they are descendants of Island Caribs and enslaved Africans who mixed among themselves in the 18th century. This population retains Caribbean culture and makes up a very small population in the archipelago, representing the 2.0% of the current population of St. Vincent and Grenadines. There are also black Caribs in Dominica and Trinidad. The history of the Black Caribs is known due to reports that the British governor William Young sent to the British crown, in which he explained that the Black Caribs were a mix of Caribs and enslaved Africans from Spanish ships wrecked near its shores. These reports were read and taken as reference by many chroniclers and later historians. However, researchers of history and Garifuna language (the Garifunas are descendants of Black Caribs in the mainland of Central America) of the 20th and 21st centuries, such as Itarala, have their own conception of the origin of the Black Caribs. According to them, the African ancestors of the Black Caribs come from other Caribbean islands and migrated to Saint Vincent as refugees to escape slavery and as slaves bought by the Carib Amerindians. The Black Caribs are the people who originated the Garifuna people, when part of their community was expelled from St. Vincent in 1797 and exported to the island of Roatán, Honduras, from where they migrated to the coast of the mainland of Central America, spread as far as Belize and Nicaragua.
BULLET::::- First Blacks in the Americas: the African presence in the Dominican Republic (CUNY Dominican Studies Institute)
